comments:
This course is the sequel to EAS 545 and focuses on the planning process for a new technology venture. EAS 546 is designed to provide hands-on experience in developing a business plan for such a venture. This course expands on topics from EAS 545, such as industry and marketplace analysis, competitive strategies related to high-tech product/service positing, marketing, development, and operations. Working in teams, students prepare a present a comprehensive business plan for a high-tech opportunity.

Many students praised the course as the “best” course that they have taken and found their learning to be “valuable” and applicable to the real business world. Emphasis was placed on presentations and group work, which some students found to be excessive.

Students generally heaped praise on Professor Cassel, describing him as “excellent,” “knowledgeable,” and “inspirational.” One student even indicated that you would have “wasted your time in Penn engineering if you haven’t taken a class with Professor Cassel”.

Overall, students found the workload for this class to be particularly intense and tough, but rewarding. Many students recommended the course to anyone who aspires to be an entrepreneur.
